There is little joy in accepting how the world has changed. Very well, we will be servants of new masters.
The omens say we must march our forces through your land. If you are sensible, you will not object.
I will use small words so that you can understand, my foreign friend: Keep. Your. Troops. Out. They cannot enter.
Do not send your hapless armies inside our borders. The stench makes crops rot in the field.
Your men are fine fellows from a distance. Close up, on our lands, they resemble brigands, dogs and lepers!
I speak only wisdom, exalted and divine. Reject us at your own peril!
Palmyra extends an honest and honourable offer to you. Do yourself a service and agree.
I feel particularly lenient today, but your refusal to cooperate might yet furrow my brow. This is best avoided.
I have words for the ears of the worthy. For the unworthy, I have only scant regard and less love!
Greetings. This time, my salutations are accompanied by a demand. Listen well!
We have a proposal for you. Consider your response carefully.
I see you quiver... There is no need, I have come to you with a simple offer.
You ask too much of Pharaoh, the protector and spirit of Egypt. I cannot send help.
I am not here to debate, dissemble or over-haggle. I come seeking acceptance of proposals made.
What I offer today, I shall not tomorrow. Palmyra needs your answer and quickly!
Our warriors are needed elsewhere, and even the sharpest sword cannot be thrust into two foes at once.
Unfortunately, your soldiers are largely unwashed and foreign. They would disturb noble Pharaoh's peace.
For today, you have agreement with the Queen of Egypt.
So, your armies, being too feeble to march against your enemies, need proper men to do their work\? No.
You stand there and ask for gold\? You can have steel, if you like, but never gold!
You are bred from awkward stock, a trait common in donkeys, but even less welcome in emissaries!
You give with one hand, and take back with the other. Well, now I use both feet to walk away!
On every path we have taken, we have turned back. I grow weary with your indecision.
I bring you the gift of choice. Choose now and choose wisely!
Enough! You haggle like the oldest of old women, forgetting what it is you are trying to buy!
Friend, speak no more. You have been a gallant advocate for your people, but you have spoken over-long.
Enough! Enough! Speak no more, for my head buzzes like a swarm of bees at your babbling!
You are wise enough not to sit idly upon the bank, but to take the fish as they swim by…
Ah, my friend, I would spare you further embarrassment! We cannot simply give you money.
Both the gods and the people are uneasy at having your troops on our soil. We must forbid you further access.
Enough, enough! My head buzzes with words, like too many angry bees! I need good ale to wash them away!
As an Egyptian and a queen I am not used to begging…
The gods have sent many signs ahead of your visit. It promises to be of great significance.
Magnificence and greatness always come at a price. And our price must, by necessity, be high…
I hope your journey was not too onerous. I look forward to hearing what you have to say.
I will send for olives, bread and wine, and then we will talk.
Be welcome! The omens are good, and I am happy to consider your proposition.
Why do you think\? This is not a philosophy lesson! You need to help in the defence. Issue the orders!
You stand idle while these cattle ticks burrow deep! Do you lack the courage for war\?
There is no shame, and much virtue, in giving to the living embodiment of Isis, the queen of Egypt!
This is the time for you to show your quality. Every Egyptian general expects your aid against these people.
Our armies, small in size, well trained, and entirely honourable in conduct, require safe passage through your lands…
My proud people treasure the blood bond between us. Do you not see this\? Will you join us\?
You are brave indeed to reject the shelter offered by Pharaoh's hand.
My people still have the strength to stand alone, and the stubbornness to reject such an offer.
Our ancestors were never beggars or servants. And we will not become your paid hirelings.
Let the wisdom of Thoth influence you now, as you harken to my plea for peace!
You think to buy us like catamites, like your whores\? You think pride and honour are for sale!
Save your gold. Sooner or later you will need a lavish funeral. I am told wailing mourners are expensive.
I am genuinely startled! I did not think your people could count up to such big numbers!
Come, share the glory and the plunder. Our gratitude will be a pleasing bonus for you.
Destiny deals many cruel blows when the gods turn away. This is just one more of those blows.
I find myself pleasantly surprised by your ability to be reasonable. I accept.
We have our agreement. Let us move onto the important matter of the celebratory feast.
The gods appear to favour you, and far be it from me to disagree. You have your deal.
A man may open his door to a friend, but the friend's servants are a different matter.
The wise help their friends in times of trouble. Do you need an extra sword against these people\?
We have gold to share with you, worthy warriors. Spoils of our battles, if you like…
Enough, I pray! I must find a crocodile to bite off my head, for it buzzes with too much talk!
You ask much of Pharaoh, Lord of All, in seeking a treaty. I do not feel generous today.
Am I always to be disturbed by foreigners\? If it is alms you want, talk to my major-domo!
Be welcome, emissary, if you come in peace. Be fearful if you come with false words, dripping with honeyed lies.
In time, two things always smell: fish and uninvited guests. Speak quickly, before I lose interest!
Before you say anything, know that I have an amulet against the evil eye. Dark sorcery will gain you naught!
Do not wander in like a desert beggar. If you have something to say, say it like a civilised man!
Do not try my patience with a dull tongue. My torturer has a collection of dullard's parts…
Must I suffer every single messenger who shuffles over my doorstep\? You have come, so speak!
Be welcome, I suppose. Now, speak as you will, and try to be interesting…
I am here, then. Speak your words, and be sure that I find profit in them!
This offer lacks a certain something. If it occurs to me later what that is I may send you a letter.
Our talk has been entertaining enough, but I do not believe anything will come of it.
Your terms are not offensive to us, but neither are they acceptable.
Why does one so worthy keep a bond to anyone so detestable\? Will you not rid yourself of commitment\?
Your arrangement with these people does you scant credit. Do your gods not mutter of their displeasure\?
I warn you against consorting with treacherous brutes. Act with honour and sever shameful ties.
Even the strongest need friends... Will you not aid us in our time of need\?
You have my attention. Now, do not try to charm. For those who do, pain is the reward.
Etruria may be the cradle of civilsation, but never let it be said we will not fight when we must. And we must, now.
From this, war must follow. The gods of the underworld are preparing places for those who fall.
It is Laran's will that we go to war with you. We would not deny the will of the gods.
The priests have read the omens, and there is only one course open to us now. We will see you on the field of battle.
War is one way to achieve one's ends, but in the end, everyone loses. We are suing for peace.
As Thesan heralds the day, so I come as the herald of peace. Will you accept my offer\?
The goods we have to offer are of the highest quality. Given your reputation, we wish to trade them with you.
Ah, this is unfortunate, but we will agree. Our armies will no longer enter your domains.
In such case, my mighty Palmyrene warriors shall seek a different route to victory.
We march our armies on other roads from this day on.
My ancestors were quite… inventive with dolts like you. They used fire, and skinning knives. Your request\? I spit on it!
Kneel before me and you will be protected and nourished in my embrace.
By sword and flame, bow before me. Don the cloak of humility and all will be well!
See reason, my friend, and follow a profitable course.
Our coffers are not so full that further tribute, from your people, would be unwelcome.
We expect loyalty from friends in times of need. We expect your armies to march to our aid.
Strength and courage in friends is not easily replaced, but we hear your words.
Perhaps someone as wealthy as you is willing to share his riches with a queen in need\?
There is much talk here of your vast treasury and boundless generosity. Is it true\?
We must bow before you in a humble request for gold, for our coffers empty too readily…
So that your dignity suffers no injury, I ask, as the Queen of Egypt, that my armies be allowed to cross your borders.
Your people are lower than camel dung, drying in the desert sun, yet you propose a treaty\?
We have been honourable foes, but now, together, we must forge an honourable peace. What say you\?
You stand there and ask for gold\? You can have steel, if you like, but never gold!
Such ripe words have their place, but I do not agree to the meat of your proposal.
Your people are lower than camel dung, drying in the desert sun, yet you propose a treaty\?
Our merchants seek prosperity in your lands. Yours could do the same in ours. Will you agree to this\?
A flight of finches against the evening sun made the will of the gods clear. It is your fate to aid our defence.
By the spirits this is sorrowful. I was about to ask you the same thing!
I think we have some spare gold around here somewhere.
fem_rome_greek_approach_demanding
Such a scheme is indeed excellent, but we must let you mount a glorious defence alone!
Have your mad gods put fire in your guts at last\? Well, burn! We will never bow to you!
No living man can claim me as his lowly servant. Did you hear me, you insignificant worm\? No!
Bow the knee\? To you\? Truly, the gods have plagued you with a dog's foaming madness!
Our gates must remain closed and barred, even to your glorious armies.
Our merchants love gold, our people love gold, even I love gold, but none of us love yours!
Your wealth will buy you many slaves to sate your lubricious and disgusting tastes. It will not buy us.
Your gold has a taint about it that cannot be washed off the fingers. We do not want it.
Trade between our lands will now end. Your merchants are as unwelcome as your coin.
Our people have their own luxuries. They want no more trade with the likes of you.
There is a season when even the river of gold must run dry. That time has come upon us.
War it is then. May your gods have mercy on you.
We welcome the chance to test ourselves against you on the field of battle.
You wish war\? In Laran's name, we will oblige you in that.
Your friendship is as much use as a broken oar at sea! Keep it to yourselves!
Egypt's treasury doors will remain resolutely shut. Do not look for gold here.
Like the caravan of merchants that has crossed a desert, it is time for us to go our separate ways.
It is a sad day when friends part company, yet such a day has come.
From this day on all treaties are broken, all agreements void, all understandings… misunderstood.
I hesitate only because I do not wish to add hurt. But you must now look to your own defence.
In the name of Baalshamin, the bonds between us must be broken; the gods have seen no single path for us.
The friendships of nations are not the same as the friendship of men. Nations do not grieve for absent comrades.
We can do little against these people. The wise among us have read the signs, and see no good in them.
I have not travelled this far for the good of my health. I come with a proposition that deserves a fair hearing.
We Rasna were making art when the younger peoples were playing in the mud. Our words have weight.
If you are wise you will listen well and consider carefully. This offer has been ratified by our priests.
My people still have the strength to stand alone, and the stubbornness to reject such an offer.
The time has come to end our arrangements. A sad day.
fem_rome_greek_approach_requesting
A treaty would be an arrow, shot with deadly intent against our mutual enemies…
We are much alike and so, in the name of Baalshamin, let there be a treaty between us.
There is much merit in a treaty between us. So speak the wise at our temples…
I come before you, clear of ill intent, with a treaty of friendship and support. Do you accept\?
A treaty between our peoples would see us all stronger and richer. Is there need of further embellishment\?
I propose a simple treaty, between equals and friends. All can profit by this offer.
The land of Etruria grows sick under the foul tread of your loutish soldiers. Remove your men from our territory at once.
Divorced with
My people cannot accept such a thing. The gods would rightly curse us!
This is a fine joke, and I laugh even as I spit my defiance in your face!
Among your own folk I am sure such idiocy passes for wit! But you are not among your own folk…
Palmyra shall never bow down to the likes of you… or anyone else, in fact!
My people do not like luxury, but money is needed. I ask, humbly, that you give us some small amount.
Take this subsidy. Our coffers are ready to burst!
We are at war. May you suffer a thousand curses, and a thousand more as payment for this folly!
Your impudence is most interesting. I wonder if it would seem so appropriate to you in a pit of scorpions\?
After much thought and consultation of the omens, I accept your terms.
I would displease the people and anger the gods were I to accept this offer.
The gods give their blessing to this offer of yours. As such, it is only right that I say yes to it.
Do you see this broken strap upon my sandal\? That is the gods telling me to refuse your terms.
Whilst I may have heard worse offers in my life, I cannot recall when. Consider your terms refused.
Will you sit, like old men in the shade, until the enemy grasps at your throat\? Or will you be warriors\?
The gods will not tolerate the presence of your armies on Etrurian soil a moment longer!
A double lightning strike on the eastern hills cannot be argued with. The gods have spoken: this war will continue.
Peace, you say\? Not while we have our pride - and our armies.
There may be a time for peace in the future. But not now.
These are feeble dogs. Say it, and we will have them skinned before the next moon!
My warlike people will set upon these jackals without mercy if you send the word!
We Rasna treasure the good things in life. I fear you have less stringent standards.
Do you require help against these scum\? We see much profit in such a course of action.
Ah, my friend, I would spare you further embarrassment! We cannot simply give you money.
Yes, we may have gold to spare. No, we do not have gold to spare for \*you\*.
Your people are lower than camel dung, drying in the desert sun, yet you propose a treaty\?
When storm clouds gather, we look for shelter and help. It is time for you to be helpful…
Let me be quite clear: I expect you to attack these insolent dogs immediately!
The love of gold can stir evil in men. Give us your gold. Avoid the evil it brings…
There is a man in my entourage who collects... parts of insolent fellows. Do you wish to meet him\?
The gods gave you a fool's face with a wit to match!
No, I will never agree! Not even if you were to drag me behind a camel to far Indus!
I should have your flayed skin nailed back onto your twitching carcass for such insolence! Instead, I will smile, slightly, at your wit…
So, you think me a child then, to make such an offer\? Remember children have nasty tempers, and sharp teeth!
Take care. Fan the flames of my anger and you will enjoy the red-hot pincers of a reply…
There are many holes in the desert, and many problems in those holes, my problematic friend.
I wonder, will you smile at your own wit if we cut off your lips and eyelids\?
The marketplace will grow quiet. Many will weep at this ending, for their living is dear to them.
Is this what you offer the queen of Palmyra\? Need I remind you that here insolence is punished by death!
I believe you have coin to spare\? If funding our armies makes you uneasy we could give it to our poets and artisans.
Think of it as an investment in future friendship.
Whatever bond we once had is now broken. You are on your own.
Expect no special treatment from now on. You had your chance to throw your lot in with us.
We leave you to your schemes, your gods and your fate.
By the spirits this is sorrowful. I was about to ask you the same thing!
Do you have a god of inertia in your pantheon\? We have sat and talked too long!
Pharaoh has quite a taste for opulence. Do you know how to satisfy it\?
Our armies are still in training and cannot attack. This proves our generals are thorough.
The arrows of war have missed their targets. Now, perhaps, it is time to talk of peace.
I offer an arrangement that will bring rest to our swords and an end to suffering.
This war is little more than a feast for vultures. Let us deny them their meal.
We can carry on war's slaughter. Only our rivals will profit by that. Or we can have peace.
Trade is the gateway to prosperity. Will you not pass within\?
We have made a desert of men's hopes, and not profited by it. Perhaps it is time for peace.
Our merchants are welcomed across all the world for the wealth they bring! Why should your lands be any different\?
War has waxed and waned, a bloody moon over our lands. Now it is time for the sun to rise.
Your people, although they do not know it yet, will find our merchandise most wondrous! Why deny them\?
We do not offer trade, we expect it. You should consider yourselves honoured that Egyptians even look at your goods!
No warrior likes standing alone in battle. Should we not be sword-brothers, and watch for each other\?
You stand to gain much from trade with us. Do not show the world you are fools by turning away.
Too many have already paid with their lives in this war.
There is much virtue in wealth and profit for all, as you will surely see after a moment's thought.
The storm has raged long enough and now, at your agreement, the softer rains of peace could be yours.
You should welcome an offer of trade. Your lands will profit much by our merchants' attentions.
We are willing to lay down their arms if you do the same. May peace reign between us.
Let us trade. You surely will not turn aside from a road paved with gold\?
We see little profit in further bloodshed. You have fought with honour, but it is time to staunch deep wounds.
Cease all hostilities! Must our people suffer needlessly by the bloodlust of generals\?
The time of bloodied blades is over; the time to sheathe them has come.
Gold is usually offered in payment for service. We are not your servants, are we\?
I say no to your request and will not attack. I cannot risk my people's safety with this request.
No. The ancestors would sleep poorly if your men were tramping across our lands.
This senseless war can end today, but only if you see matters as they are, not as you wish to.
The plan is good, but we cannot send warriors to help in defence. Our wise women have spoken against it.
In the name of Aglibol! We have talked and talked but I have heard enough.
Gossip and chit-chat are all very well for old women at the well, but I have better things to do!
I wonder how long this pointless discussion will last\? We'd best interrupt it right now.
I can listen no more! The day is nearly done. For you, it is over.
Our words have flopped about like fish out of water, but have given us nothing to gnaw upon.
Enough! My mind is weary with chatter. The wine grows stale, and it was not of the best anyway.
The storm clouds do indeed gather. That is your problem - you have offended the gods.
Gold is usually offered in payment for service. We are not your servants, are we\?
Do you see that pattern in the clouds\? The gods show their displeasure, so I must conclude our dealings.
Your opening chord caught my attention but the song was tuneless and overly long. I will listen no more.
The offer has grown stale on your lips. I do not think I can bear to spend any more time on this.
Allow this\? I will not risk the honour of our women with your ruffians near at hand!
We offer this as a sign of accord reached, and new accords to come.
Your armies stand at risk. We have troops who could help. That is the thrust of my offer here.
I pledge to protect you in your struggle. Surely you need my spear in these desperate times\?
The soldiers of Palmyra are at the ready. You only need to whisper and they will march.
It will take time to remove the taint of this agreement.
Yes, it's very nice gold, but the portents indicate that we should never take it from scum.
It is war, then. May the holy crocodiles grow bored with feasting on thy rotting carcasses!
My friend, our coffers already overflow with wealth from all corners of the world. We need no more!
My people have riches enough. Your gesture is polite, but not needed.
Your intent here is plain, but to accept your money would put us, ever-so-slightly, in your debt.
There is glory to be had! Attack! Do not sit back and watch from the safety of the hills.
We need the glory of battle! Let us stand with you against these darkling foes!
I think not. Our riches outshine your own treasures a thousand fold, and you would feel ashamed.
Although gold is beneath the notice of Pharaoh, divine mistress of Egypt, her servants have mortal, prosaic concerns…
I implore you not to let our peoples be separated. United in greatness, do we not all gain\?
I promise to withdraw my forces from your lands. They are, after all, your lands. For now.
Our armies will march away. By my heart, you will be poorer when their magnificence is gone!
Very well. Our soldiers will leave, if that is truly your desire. They were, I thought, helping your ruffians!
Join us! We must put an end to these creatures once and for all!
My people do not like luxury, but money is needed. I ask, humbly, that you give us some small amount.
Since you are so deferent, I must accept.
The danger is now pressing. I will cast pride aside and beg you for aid lest my people suffer.
Very funny. Oh wait, you were not joking\? Well then you are patently insane.
The warriors of Palmyra need to pass through your lands. You shall not be inconvenienced by them.
We have need for our armies to pass through your lands. Will you agree to this humble request\?
Our armies seek a route through your lands. They will act with respect and good order.
Dogs who bare their teeth must often be whipped to their kennels. Do you want our armies to attack\?
Can you not attack these peasants\? They offend the sensibilities of Pharaoh, the daughter of the morning.
It is in your interests to allow our troops into your territory.
Strength and bravery have been shown by the living and the dead. Now it is time to set aside war…
Thieves do not get the keys to the treasury. They get the gelding knife.
So, you think us dotards who will pay because we have no memory of services rendered\? Fool!
Ah, the gods blessed you with a fool's face and a sense of fun! Gold\? Now that is for grown-ups…
The time has come to end our arrangements. A sad day.
You are most worthy friends, but your treaty with these folk is distressing. Can you not break it\?
We do not pay wolves to keep them from our flocks. When we can be bothered, we hunt them.
All treaties between us are ended. I, the Divine Pharaoh, have ordered it so.
A river of goods and coin between our lands would surely see all prosper. Will you agree to trade\?
I will save a special arrow, just for you. Look for me on the battlefield.
I am sure your words carry a cargo of honest intent, but they hold no value for my people.
I cannot accept your offer. My head cautions me against your clever words.
Your speak well, and you offer much, but I cannot give agreement here.
Your offer is well meant, but it is not as good as I had hoped.
You serve your masters well, but you do not yet make a convincing argument for me.
Despite your eloquent advocacy, my good friend, we cannot agree to these terms.
Your gods have not, I fear, given you the power of divine persuasion. I cannot agree.
The gods gave you a clever tongue, but you have not yet used it to say what I need to hear.
Our haggling must, I think, continue a little longer. Your proposal lacks what I seek.
You presume much by coming here today. Perhaps you are not aware with whom you are dealing\?
Make your case with speed and honesty. I am a busy man, and have no time for dissemblers.
It is a shame you are not as sensitive to the omens as I, else you might not have wasted time coming.
So, you have come. Let us hear what you have to say then.
I have listened long to your witty speeches, but I cannot agree what lies behind that wit.
You are brave indeed to reject the shelter offered by Pharaoh's hand.
Perhaps you will find profit in setting aside our friendship\? Although, for the life of me, I wonder where…
The sooner you accept that the gods wish you to serve us, the sooner we may return to more civilsed pursuits.
Our armies' route takes them through your lands. I trust this will not be an issue.
No, by the blade of Aglibol, no! Not a single sword will be drawn for such a pathetic and unprofitable cause!
You put your head into the lion's mouth by yourself, you fool. We will not stay its bite.
Are you small children, then, to hide behind a grown-up's legs when danger comes\?
Magnificence and greatness always come at a price. And our price must, by necessity, be high…
Only a goat eats everything within reach! You were birthed by a goat! You smell like one as well!
Come, we do not ask for much, and your continued generosity would no doubt please the gods.
You take me for a fool\? You will not see a single one of our coins, you wretch!
Where is your begging bowl\?
Find your own money for catamites, whores and trinkets!
It is simple: allow our troops to march through your lands and you'll have the queen's gratitude.
A noble act worthy of your ancestors. The gods accept your offering.
We give our oaths to you and your people, and lend our honour and warriors to your cause.
We have gold to share with you, worthy warriors. Spoils of our battles, if you like…
If you strike, the blow will be unexpected and all the stronger for it! Can you not march\?
It is true, we glory in battle but we are not murderers in the dark. Find other tame killers…
Let it be understood that a simple tribute honours both you, the giver, and me the recipient.
Do you have a grand gift as a fitting expression of friendship\?
I am accustomed to gifts worthy of my magnificence. I hope you have such a thing.
I agree, and admire your sense and clear thinking in this matter. My people will rejoice!
The love of gold can stir evil in men. Give us your gold. Avoid the evil it brings…
This is foolishness disguised as a particularly poor joke. The answer must be no. You are, after all, not Egyptians!
I hope that this offer of coins will be taken in the right spirit of comradeship and respect!
Take this subsidy. Our treasuries were over-full!
We are richer than the kings of Persia and wish for you to partake in our wealth.
On behalf of my people, I accept. The haggling is done, and we have an end to our talk!
We can ask no more. Your proposal is wise, honourable and, I hope, pregnant with future profit!
I accept. When two ride on the same camel they become better friends or they slit each other's throats!
You present honest terms that I accept and will present to my people.
I recognise the merit in this proposal. It shall be carried out!
We have good reason to accept such terms. My people will give thanks, I am sure.
I cannot agree, my friend. Chance may have been unkind, but the gods have yet to finish their game!
This is not a sensible proposition. Perhaps you have a stolen camel you want me to buy instead\?
I had not noticed that the gods had cursed us, and ordered that we were to be your chattel goods.
You think we can be bought so easily\? Try your cheap persuasions on a younger and more foolish people.
We do not feel that trade with you has brought us sufficient profit, and wish to end it.
These people trouble even the gods! I beg you: march against them before it is too late!
We trust you have thought long on this; it may eventually invite great sorrow for your people.
So it is done! You have shown great prudence in your choices today.
I will be honest. I seek coin as a token of your good and continued friendship.
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you join with us.
The Queen of Egypt gives you greetings - I come to speak plainly of my desires.
Attack these folk\? We bear the burdens while you reap the profits, I think! I refuse this stupidity!
Your notion is as wrong-headed as it is cur-like in delivery! Our armies do not bleed for you.
I will have no more of your pointless warmongering. I will not fight for you!
The signs are positive. With the gods on our side, I see no reason not to accept your excellent offer.
You show a wisdom and wit which would credit Menerva herself. I agree.
I am happy to agree to that. Let us seal the deal with fresh wine and fine food.
Our warriors will trouble neither man nor beast in your lands… Your women\? I cannot promise that…
My people cannot accept such a thing. The gods would rightly curse us!
Your association with these people offends the gods. Will you not cut ties with them before it is too late\?
My people will never be obedient to your rule. Go to the slave market if you need servants!
Do not look for shade from the noon heat in our tent!
As the Nile rises to bring bounty, we should hope for a flood of trade between our lands!
We are out of wine, sweetmeats and, in my case, patience. Can we not bring this to a close\?
The gods themselves would be pressed to endure such lengthy negotiations!
My will is a stalwart shield against anyone who wishes to do you harm.
I had heard that you were as wearisome as a stubborn camel, yet this is not even slightly true!
I trust that you can face your gods without them visiting you with boils after this…
An honourable choice. You have shelter from the storm for as long as you remain faithful servants.
You will come to love serving the Queen of Palmyra. Rest assured, bright days are ahead.
I seek acceptance on certain matters that could result in common gain for our peoples. Shall we begin\?
Please accept, as a most humble audience for your terms, my poor self. Now, speak as you will.
An end to over-long talk! Your offer is not what I want to hear! My throat yearns for ale, my ears for silence!
Excellent! We have agreement. Your mouth talks well. Let us see if your belly can hold ale!
So you know how to haggle and when to stop! An offer accepted is a blessing to all!
We have driven too hard a bargain or haggled overlong, it seems. Very well, your decision is made.
My friend, if the wisdom you possess were golden treasure, you could buy the known world!
I see that your course is set. Truly, I hope your gods gave you wisdom and not false counsel.
Your wisdom in this matter is a credit to your people, better than any golden coin!
I think that many will regret your choice. Let us hope that regrets come singly, not like Roman Legions!
Your acceptance is welcome and fills my heart with delight. May Yarhibol smile upon your prudence!
An unwise, even foolish, choice but we respect your… independence… of thought.
An excellent decision! Your head masters your passion with wisdom.
I fear you have turned your people from a path of prosperity and sent them towards misfortune.
You serve your people with honour and will surely win the favour of your gods.
I hear and honour your judgement my friend, even if its wisdom escapes me…
A wise choice. Why lead your people through the mountains when a straight road lies ahead\?
You have proven a worthy negotiator. All will rejoice at this outcome.
I thought more of you and your people. But your choice is made, and now you must live with it.
Your heart and love for your people guide you well today.
Your lack of acceptance is disappointing, but the camel will not hear that roast goat is delicious.
Greetings! As rain brings life to the barren desert so will my words pour joy into your heart.
Only you are worthy of my personal attention. My offer shall go to no other ruler, mighty as he may be.
I humbly await an audience. Do not turn me away.
I seek acceptance for terms that will surely bring progress to all our lands.
You are a trusted friend of Palmyra. It is to you alone that I bring the following proposal...
I respectfully ask for an attack on these people, as soon as can be arranged..
I welcome this chance to speak, for I think you will find what I say is of much interest…
We ask only a little: turn your mighty fist against this most annoying of foes!
Greetings, friend. I bring a treasure of words that will surely find favour with your people.
These brazen fools deserve only death. Can your mighty generals take the butcher's blade to them\?
I thank you for this audience. You should find the words I bring more than interesting.
Well met. I speak, the devoted servant of my people, to one who we would name a friend.
Now that words have failed, become a mortician. It's the only way you may profit from this war!
The bond between our peoples is broken. Do not look for us when you are in need.
Dogs circle us and bare their teeth. We need a friend or two to watch our backs…
I make a simple request, and with respect: can you not spare some gold for my people\?
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you join with us.
Left alone, this threat may grow to endanger us both. However, if you attack them now...
We offer this as a sign of accord reached, and new accords to come.
A proposal such as this will bring little for the people of Palmyra. No!
There is little merit in such an arrangement for my people. I can see the appeal of the idea to you…
You undoubtedly think your offer generous but it is only the direst insult, and I reject it.
Together we have the might to make all tremble. Consider this well before you decide.
