These beasts sleep, but they may yet hunt us both. Will you strike while they slumber\?
Enter, friend, and speak. We surely have much to discuss, and perhaps much to agree!
Our coffers are not so full that further tribute, from your people, would be unwelcome.
I believe we may be able to help with your 'little problem'.
I will take word of our agreement and put it before my people. They will  feast in celebration!
Your generosity will long be remembered by my people and the gods.
As the sun rises and the moon sets, the season has come for you to accept divine Pharaoh.
What I ask is such a little thing, an inconsequential thing, that I almost hesitate to mention the amount…
We make this modest request in the knowledge that your coffers strain to contain your wealth…
We humbly ask for a single, modest subsidy to help our people through a dark time…
We have asked much of our warriors. Now, I beg, let them rest.
Can you spare men to cut a few throats\? These people need death. They would welcome it at your hands…
We would find beggars at the gates every day if we gave you money. I fear we must refuse.
Ah, my friend, you ask too much. Gold is happiest with gold it knows, not in a stranger's vaults.
Scant respect would be yours if friendship is purchased! We hold you in much higher regard!
A suitable gift for the Queen of Egypt. She abides!
Our ancestors were never beggars or servants. And we will not become your paid hirelings.
You have a chance here to prove that there is no greater loyalty than to friends in need!
Your merchants are renowned as honourable traders. They would be welcome at our markets!
I will be honest. I seek coin as a token of your good and continued friendship.
Strength and courage in friends is not easily replaced, but we hear your words.
I find myself genuinely perplexed that you consider your friendship so desirable.
Did you not consult your gods before making such an offer\? If so you have misread the signs.
This is not a sensible proposition. Perhaps you have a stolen camel you wish to sell instead\?
Our lands would never be rid of the stench. You may not march in them.
My people are not your shield. Are you so sunk in cowardice\? You are geldings indeed, then!
This is good. The gods will smile on our agreement, and all will be satisfied.
Your ideas are undoubtedly strong within your own mind, but in my ears they are nothing.
Our wise women have looked into the flame; they see no good in trade with you.
I speak with honest and honourable tongue. I demand that you listen with equal honesty!
Accept my proposal and we can reap the fruits of our concord.
It is time to speak with an eye to mutual profit. I offer this because you are an intelligent man.
Do not look for an answer to my words at the bottom of a wine cup, friend.
If you truly serve your gods, you keep a clear mind and think carefully on what I say.
Your next move is simple: you take this offer and we both prosper from it!
My offer is shaped intricately and with great care. Do not dismiss my words lightly.
You honour me by your attention, worthy listener! I wish to speak of many matters…
When I hunt, I look for sport. When I speak, I look for honest answers.
I speak with a simple tongue, without trickery. Accept or do not accept, but do so honestly.
As the sun rises and the moon sets, the season has come for you to accept divine Pharaoh.
Speak of this again and I will have you disembowelled and sent back to your people in canopic jars!
One sacrifice is needed, on the altar of our goodwill. I speak of silver, of course…
There is little worth in these terms and therefore I must reject!
Your inferior goods hold no appeal. Try trading with someone else similarly lacking in skill and good taste.
We will have peace when your last warrior has fallen and your peoples' spirits are broken.
We have suffered insults and slights, taken casualties and lost heroes. No, we will not stop until this conflict is done.
Do you think Etruria's age means we are in our dotage\? We Rasna did not survive this long by backing down from a fight!
We fire this arrow straight and true. It is up to you to snatch it from the air.
Come, my friend, speak! You and I both serve our people with honour; there is no greater good than this.
Welcome friend! Let us conclude our business with good haste, and then... a feast!
Welcome, friend, welcome! Come, sit! Enjoy the pleasures of my home, and let us find accord!
Speak, my friend! Be not alarmed that you stand in my presence - today we are equals.
I will do you the honour of listening to your terms, hoping to hear wisdom and profit in them.
I greet you as befits your reputation. Now, friend, speak plainly so that we may fall to haggling!
Your generosity is astounding, but I cannot be bought like a camel at market.
I greet you in friendship. Speak in honesty, and you will be answered likewise.
Greetings, friend. Let us use our time together in wisdom, and seek accord.
You have an honest face, even as you offer an honest bribe. I must, in all politeness, refuse.
I will be a patient audience for your speech, sure that you come to deliver a profitable message.
Your generous nature does your people credit, but really such a thing is not necessary.
Our warriors will pass through your lands. Be wise, and leave the door ajar…
A treaty with us would create a true force to be reckoned with.
The time has come to consider how we might both benefit from the developing situation.
An alliance would benefit us both, do you not think\? All the omens point to it…
Your prattling has given me a headache. Hopefully it will be cured by a cup of cool wine, and your immediate departure.
You have the temerity to suggest \*we\* should serve \*you\*\? A ridiculous thought, though sadly typical of the younger peoples!
We Rasna are an old and civilised people but our patience is not infinite. Enough talk.
There is no shame, and much virtue, in giving to the living embodiment of Isis, the queen of Egypt!
Friendship does not rely on a form of words, my friend. It is found in deeds.
Welcome, honoured emissary. Speak plainly and you shall be rewarded.
Could the forces of Etruria be of assistance in your current travails\? I have the authority to offer such help.
You show generosity. On behalf of my people, I give you due thanks.
Propose a marriage between their faction leader and yours. Such a marriage results in greatly improved diplomatic relations between the two factions.
Your impudence is most interesting. I wonder if it would seem so appropriate to you in a pit of scorpions\?
The queen, wise strategist and brave leader of all of Egypt, requests that you attack these people when you are able.
There has been much blood, it is true. Now you ask for peace. We, however, find profit in blood.
The gods rightly wish us to show humility, and not enrich ourselves at your expense.
Your plea for mercy is well spoken, but not pleasing to our ears. The war continues.
Our merchants do not want trade with you. I must take note of their desires.
You dangle peace before us: a pretty trinket. But glory, that magnificent treasure, is within our grasp!
Trade with you is, I am sorry to say, all but impossible. Our merchants have business elsewhere.
The gods blessed you with some good sense. Unfortunately for you, they gave us scant forgiveness.
By the flame, you have a fool's courage! Your peace is a shiny trinket, and finds no buyer here!
You may well talk of peace! I myself have asked for the moon and stars and a flying horse made of ebony!
Our armies will march beneath a banner of peace through your lands. It is our rivals who should know fear!
Do not worry, when and if we want your gold, we will take it from you.
My people will never be obedient to your rule. Go to the slave market if you need servants!
Do you require help against these scum\? We see much profit in such a course of action.
I am sent to speak to you, and hear words. I must have offended many gods to be given this reward!
You wish our armies to leave\? A short-sighted move, I feel, given the comparative states of our forces.
The scorpion's sting is more gentle than a refusal, but a refusal is all I can offer.
Arrange Marriage...
Do not waste friendship on these ungrateful dogs, I beg you! These creatures will turn on you!
This is a fine joke, and I laugh even as I spit my defiance in your face!
The Divine Pharaoh, heir to Osiris, is no stranger to war, but requests that you make it…
Do I look like a fool to you, to accept such a laughable proposition\?
I have better things to do than negotiate with witless idiots.
By all the gods, I would rather spend a year in Aita's realm than another moment listening to you!
Your impudence is most interesting. I wonder if it would seem so appropriate to you in a pit of scorpions\?
Gold aplenty is a comfort to anyone. We would think well of you if you were to give some small coins…
You speak well for your people, and my heart and head are persuaded. You have an agreement with Egypt!
No. Your speech is polite, but for the queen, Lord of Upper and Lower Egypt, courtesy is not enough.
We would forever be indebted to you if your worthy generals attacked these monsters!
Pharaoh has quite a taste for opulence. Do you know how to satisfy it\?
Will you not come to the aid of Pharaoh, the shield of her people\? These creatures must be stopped!
The love of gold can stir evil in men. Give us your gold. Avoid the evil it brings…
Perhaps, good friend, you will consider that these lands could be more… prosperous under Palmyrene rule\?
Do you, always wise in statecraft, not see the wisdom in surrendering these lands to our control\?
I humbly request that you see fit to give these people to our rule so that all may prosper.
Bow down to you\? We were composing heroic odes before you people had even mastered the basics of polite conversation.
Welcome, friend-to-be of Pharaoh, the Master of Two Houses! Tell her now of your desires.
I thank you for the offer, but we are not wet nurses for weaklings.
We wish our armies to march across your lands. I am sure that this will cause you no problems.
We want you as friends of our people. So will you accept the hand of friendship, or turn away\?
I will listen further, my good and honest friend, in the hopes you have a proper offer to make.
We make this modest request in the knowledge that your coffers strain to contain your wealth…
Can you help our defence against these people\?
Your friendship is as much use as a broken oar at sea! Keep it to yourselves!
Our young warriors crave the chance to earn their rights as men! Your blood will wash away their youth!
Your people, although they do not know it yet, will find our merchandise most wondrous! Why deny them\?
So, you think us dotards, who will pay because we have no memory\? You fool!
I always check the teeth of a camel before I buy it. This beast is definitely good only for soup.
My friend, I had hoped for a feast. Instead, I am served crumbs...
My friend, I had not noticed my feathers, for surely you think me a carrion bird, to offer such scraps!
This offer is a poor one. Even a beggar in the marketplace would haggle over such a small coin!
This is a fine joke, and I laugh even as I spit my defiance in your face!
I can give voice to no acceptance, and have no stomach for insolence.
We are not so bent with the weight of the world that we will bow to this offer.
Your offer is like a gust of wind over the desert - it whistles for a while and then dissipates.
I am not a sun-drunk fool, seeking water at any price.
Such a thing cannot be countenanced. Our people, not to mention our gods, would forever mutter and be displeased.
Freedom is of little use once a sword-thrust sends you to the underworld. The price of our protection is not high.
These lands would, I think, flourish under your stewardship. We say claim them as your own!
These people are not inclined to live like true Palmyrenes. Perhaps they will do better under your rule.
This land I bestow upon you is a token of our respect, nothing more.
My people are wise and worthy masters. Be wise, and take the expected oaths. You may still prosper.
Your acceptance is as welcome as a cool evening breeze after the desert's heat.
Your decision is, I hope, not as foolish as it first appears. Perhaps Thoth will visit you later…
We have consulted the gods. They have given us no favourable signs. You will understand, I hope.
You show much wisdom in seeking us as friends, but we must rely on our own strength.
The merits of a treaty seem to favour you above us. That I cannot accept.
You have spoken long and well, but words alone are not enough to convince me.
Friendship does not rely on a form of words, my friend. It is found in deeds.
You have a determined tongue but there is no profit in what you suggest.
My people still have the strength to stand alone, and the stubbornness to reject such an offer.
We do not offer trade, we expect it. You should consider yourselves honoured that Egyptians even look at your goods!
This is unfortunate, but we agree. Our armies will no longer enter your domain.
Only a goat eats everything within reach! You were birthed by a goat! You smell like one as well!
Can you not attack these folk\? Your bravery in this would surely be worthy of a bard's song!
I will listen carefully to your words, and then give judgement. So, greetings, and now: business!
There is little worth in these terms and therefore I must reject!
Your friendship is as much use as a broken oar at sea! Keep it to yourselves!
We have made a desert of men's hopes, yet not profited by it. Perhaps it is time for peace\?
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you unite with us.
So be it. Look to your own gods for safety. We will look to our swords.
I fear you have chosen a path after too much wine, rather than with good sense…
If this is your wish, so be it. I am puzzled as to how you profit by this ending.
Very well, our arrangement is over. The winds will blow us as they will, to whatever fate awaits…
The bond between our peoples is broken. Do not look for us as friends in the marketplace.
We are done. Do not look for shade in our tent from the desert heat at noon.
I am sent to speak to you, and hear words. I must have offended many gods to be given this reward!
There is much to be said for generosity between friends. It profits both parties, don't you agree\?
We must now speak of money. Our coffers will have some of yours to ensure the goodwill of the public.
I will be honest. I seek coin as token of your good and continued friendship.
Do you wish only to be remembered for war\? Trade with us, and learn what it is to be truly civilised.
You want peace\? Peace\? Now\? Gods give me strength to let this fool live and carry away my refusal!
Peace\? We will have peace, but only when you moonstruck and deformed imbeciles are impaled on stakes! And worse!
The bond between our peoples is broken. Do not look for us when you are in need.
For a moment I thought you were asking for peace! What a fine joke!
How can anyone not wish for the riches we have to trade\? Our metalwork and sculpture are unsurpassed.
You plead for peace. Plead some more. Grovel, even, but above all, know that we do not want it.
No, and our people will give thanks to the gods for this refusal of your dung-stench rubbish!
War achieves only short-term gains. It is time to try the civilised option: peace.
Peace. Or war. Is war until you are dead a mature and sensible course\? No, but we want it!
I have heard that merchants give short weight, cannot add coin, and lie. Why would we want trade\?
Only the youngest and most foolish peoples cannot see when it is time for the fighting to end.
You ask for peace. Ask until the new moon comes, until the world ends, and you will still have war!
Did I hear you correctly\? You want to trade\? No. Our people do not crave worthless baubles.
The people and the priests agree that this war has run its course. Let us have peace.
I thank you for the offer, but we are not wet nurses for weaklings.
My people are wise and worthy masters. Be wise, and take the expected oaths. You may still prosper.
This is foolishness disguised as a particularly poor joke. The answer must be no. You are, after all, not Egyptians!
Whilst we are not exactly \*insulted\* by your needy gesture, we do not feel inclined to accept it.
Your wisdom in this matter is a credit to your people - better than any coin!
I see that your course is set. Truly, I hope your gods gave you wisdom and not false counsel.
The scorpion's sting is more gentle than a refusal, but a refusal is all I can offer.
Your talk has wandered along too many paths. I am lost, and ready to go home! No more talk today!
We have tolerated the stink of your armies long enough. Now, remove them from our lands!
The very dust groans beneath the boots of your foul warriors! Get them off our lands!
Remove your men from our lands at once, lest our gods are roused and our people, in fear, demand action!
Tyrant! Dictator! Despot! Monster! Child-killer! Never shall we bow in obedience to you. That is madness!
A tribute fit for a queen! I graciously accept your generosity and friendship.
This is a noble gesture and fitting tribute to the magnificence of my people.
I am rarely swayed by gifts but I accept your offering with gratitude.
Our armies seek a route through your lands. They will act in good order and with great respect.
There is little honour in spectating. I ask, in humility: join the fray and taste glory!
Well met, friend! Sit, and let your words move me to anger or agreement, as you wish of them!
We will walk the warriors' road together then. At its end stands your funeral pyre. I will bring the torch!
I will speak plainly: the queen, concerned for the safety of her people, requests you aid our defence.
You speak with wisdom and grace. We accept and embrace your offer!
A simple tribute is all that is expected and needed. Then all can be fair words between us.
We only demand a modest weight of coin, yet always look kindly on generosity…
As vast as our coffers are, there is still space to be filled.
This is good. The gods will smile on our agreement, and all will be satisfied.
I cannot settle on such terms. It would not serve my people to give in to such haggling.
You speak a foreign tongue, and yet you bargain as well as I do! This is most welcome!
Your cunning would shame a Cappadocian grandmother, haggling over dates! And no, I do not agree.
Your offer is fair, although I do wonder if you missed your calling. Friend, you should be selling second-hand camels!
An acceptance would offend my gods, even as yours giggled about it!
The Queen of Egypt, most unforgetting, may be appreciative of your monetary support.
Your proposal has merit. Yes, yes… I see much benefit in what you say.
Your ideas are undoubtedly golden within your heart and head, but in my ears they are dust.
You have haggled with a clever tongue. Such a settlement will serve Palmyra well.
You speak well for your people, my friend, but your words today have not convinced me.
I know a bargain when I see one. It is agreed!
While your words are spoken in honesty, they offer little to please the Palmyrene Queen.
These are feeble dogs. Say it, and we will have them skinned before the next moon!
Never let it be said that we Rasna are not generous.
Welcome, worthy friend! Let us break bread and drink before words pass our lips!
These people are a danger. Your generals are well placed to trample these insolent wretches. Can you do this\?
Only the gods could snatch those lands from my grip.
These people are loyal servants, and deserve our loyalty in return. You cannot have their lands.
I admire good manners but they are not sufficient in this case - this land will remain in my possession.
Will you give over these lands to the people of Palmyra\?
There are a thousand reasons why these lands should be ours. Well\?
I have a simple question, requiring a simple answer: Will you hand over these lands\?
Why does one so worthy keep ties with one so detestable\? Will you not rid yourself of this commitment\?
The time has come to end our arrangements. A sad day.
Your notion is as wrong-headed as it is cur-like in delivery! Our armies do not bleed for you.
All treaties between us are ended. I, the Divine Pharaoh, have ordered it so.
The gods have spoken through our priests. A treaty with you would be most beneficial to all concerned.
For one of the younger peoples, you show great promise. Would you consider future cooperation\?
We accept the protection so kindly offered.
Such ripe words have their place, but I do not agree to the meat of your proposal.
I make a simple request, and with respect: can you not spare some gold for my people\?
Before you say anything, know that I have an amulet against the evil eye. Dark sorcery will gain you naught!
You are brave indeed to reject the shelter offered by Pharaoh's hand.
The priests inform me that our alliance no longer pleases the gods, therefore it must end.
Perhaps you will find profit in setting aside our friendship\? Although, for the life of me, I wonder where…
Every song must end, every poem conclude. Our alliance has served its purpose but now it is over.
Lightning struck the temple last night. It is a clear sign that the time has come for our paths to diverge.
I make a simple request, and with respect: can you not spare some gold for my people\?
Our coffers are not so full that further tribute, from your people, would be unwelcome.
Speak of this again and I will have you disembowelled and sent back to your people in canopic jars!
Are you small children, then, to hide behind grown-ups when danger comes\?
Prophecy tells of these lands in our hands. Do not stand by and idly defy prophecy!
These people cry out for our just rule. Give these lands over to us.
Your men are fine fellows from a distance. Close up, on our lands, they resemble brigands, dogs and lepers!
I have no doubt that you will see sense and hand over these territories immediately.
Surely you can see that now is the time to break all treaties and agreements with these worthless brigands\?
For all your assurances that your troops would behave themselves, we have no desire to allow such ruffians onto our land.
I will be a patient audience for your speech. Be sure that you bring a profitable message.
The needs of my people are simple: some of your fine trading goods in exchange for our wares. Well\?
Your intent here is plain, but to accept your money would put us in your debt.
We cannot. Our armies are but cunning shadows for our defence, not for rash attacks.
We can do little against these people. The gods are silent in their temples and this is an ill omen by itself.
A thousand apologies, but such help as we could offer would arrive too late and be of little use.
This is foolishness disguised as a particularly poor joke. The answer must be no. You are, after all, not Egyptians!
Magnificence and greatness always come at a price. And our price must, by necessity, be high…
Can you not see, my good friend, that defence against these beasts is a necessity\? Will you help\?
Your men will turn the enemies' bowels to water! Come, aid us in this war, I beg!
You have a chance here to prove that there is no greater loyalty than to friends in need!
We find ourselves facing mountain wolves, and would welcome an extra sword or two in our defence!
Enough, I beg! Your words are like arrows loosed by a blind man: none reach the target!
There is no shame, and much virtue, in giving to the living embodiment of Isis, the queen of Egypt!
That you are willing to offer such ongoing incentives says much about the depths of your desperation.
It is a terrible thing to spread war across the world but, I beg you, attack these wretches!
Friendship does not rely on a form of words, my friend. It is found in deeds.
Could we march our forces through your territory\? They are a well-disciplined lot and will not cause trouble.
The best ale is of little comfort to a dry throat when talk results in nothing.
Talk can be tasteless, but when we have agreement it makes wine sweeter and gives meat savour!
Only a goat eats everything within reach! You were birthed by a goat! You smell like one as well!
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you join with us.
My people cannot accept such a thing. The gods would rightly curse us!
I will be honest. I seek coin as a token of your good and continued friendship.
Your thoughts dash from river to desert like a maddened jackal! Speak no more, for we are done!
Such ripe words have their place, but I do not agree to the meat of your proposal.
I say this: if we do not stand, back to back, with sword and shield, jackals will drag us down!
Think very carefully on this offer, and remember that a wise man knows the value of his strongest friends.
I will not demand agreement to a treaty, but I may think aloud about the consequences of refusal…
I pray I do not have cause to regret this agreement.
I offer this: an alliance against our enemies. Let us crush them into the dust, and see their blood soak the land!
I say this: together we have the might to make all enemies tremble. Consider this well.
The omens cannot be argued with. But that is the only reason I am agreeing to this.
Will you stand by us or cast friendship aside\?
I am far from happy but you have my word on this. I will try and see the upside.
Undoubtedly, dire need haunts you, however, Palmyrene generosity has been reduced to a trickle of late.
We do not give subsidies to passing acquaintances. Perhaps that is why our treasury bulges!
I think not. Our gold would outshine your other treasures' worth a thousand fold, and you would feel shame.
Friendship does not rely on a form of words, my friend. It is found in deeds.
Would you require my royal help against these people\?
…or we could tip our riches into the sea, slit the throats of our animals and break our swords on our knees. It might save time.
We would sooner join forces with a pack of rabid dogs.
Only the dark gods celebrate this war and its suffering. I ask you to think of this, and give us peace.
You require assistance from mighty Pharaoh\? Bow lower!
Will you sit, like old men in the shade, until enemies grasp at your throat\? Or will you be warriors\?
War rages and you still stand idle\? Has it come to this\? Stand and fight!
The time is right for an attack on these wretches. Are you ready to carry it out\?
The mighty host of Palmyra will soon be at your gates. They merely pass through, hunting other game…
Our armies will march beneath a banner of peace in your lands. It is our rivals who should know fear!
My friend, allow the Palmyrene generals to use your lands as a highway, a road to their rightful destination.
I had hoped that you were a philosopher, and marshalled ire with good reasoning. I see I was wrong.
It seems we must find an alternative route around your lands. How irritating.
Excellent! Now let us drink to ease our throats, and have music to ease our ears!
Other routes will suit our armies just as well, I'm sure.
As the gods are my witness, you have brought this upon yourself. We will not waste Etruscan lives on your folly!
This is a fine joke, and I laugh even as I spit my defiance in your face!
Our defences need reinforcement. If we are conquered, how long until you are threatened also\?
One sacrifice is needed, on the altar of our goodwill. I speak of silver, of course…
Take this subsidy. Our coffers are ready to burst!
Our coffers are locked to you. Unless the gods indicate a wish for us to throw away our riches, they will remain so.
We make this modest request in the knowledge that your coffers strain to contain your wealth…
The omens are clear - the gods decree an alliance. Do not dare defy them!
I do not believe your contribution to our economy was particularly significant anyway.
There are plenty of other markets out there...
Etruria will endure long after your name is forgotten. We will not even give a handful of our soil over to you!
The queen, lord of the living and the dead, laughs at your pathetic attempts to buy safety with Egyptian lives!
We Rasna are no man's slave!
No temple can stand upon just two pillars. We cannot agree.
Gold aplenty is a comfort to anyone. We would think well of you if you were to give some small coins…
Our defences are weak, and our old folk know fear. Can you send men to help against the foe\?
Are you willing to carry out an attack\? Palmyra asks so little of you!
Come! Profit from this war! Order your generals to march and attack!
If you strike the blow will be unexpected and all the stronger for it! Can you not march\?
What you give with one hand, you claw back with the other. I will use both feet to walk away!
You must stand alone. Our armies, I find, exist more in the treasurer's accounts than reality…
Our swords are blunted, and our armies in need of drill. We cannot come to your defence.
Such a scheme is indeed excellent, but we must let you mount a glorious and successful defence!
Say your piece like a civilised man, outlander! The Pharaoh, Lord of All, has no time for babble!
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you unite with us.
You ask much of Pharaoh, Lord of All, in seeking a treaty. I do not feel generous today.
My friend, I will plead that you do only this: listen to the gods and join this war!
I beg you: consider the glory lost forever if your troops stand aside in this war!
I am sure you see that lending Palmyra aid in this conflict will bring many benefits.
My people are wise and worthy masters. Be wise, and take the expected oaths. You may still prosper.
Well met. Perhaps we may speak together after I have refreshed myself\?
Many speak highly of your sharp mind and farsightedness. I look forward to experiencing them.
Attack them\? Why, in the name of Cel and Tin, would we ever consider doing your dirty work\?
Strength and courage in friends is not easily replaced, but we hear your words.
I have high hopes that you will see the sense in my proposition.
Are you brave or foolish\? Or just mad\? Well speak, I will listen before I turn you inside out!
I advise you to listen to what I have to say, if you have your people's interests at heart.
I come to you only after detailed consultation of the omens. Listen, consider, and act with wisdom.
My time is precious but it is yours for now. I pray you will not waste it.
My people will never be obedient to your rule. Go to the slave market if you need servants!
Our armies need a peaceful path through your lands. We expect you will allow this.
The time has come for my army to march across your territory. There is no reason for you to object, is there\?
I am sure you understand that it is in your interests to allow our troops into your territory.
I thank you for the offer, but we are not wet nurses for weaklings.
You ask much of Pharaoh, Lord of All, in seeking a treaty. I do not feel generous today.
No temple can stand upon just two pillars. We cannot agree.
We humbly request that you teach these fools a hard lesson.
It is simple. Move your armies to aid us. Or have the world think you poor friends and weaklings.
We expect loyalty from friends at a time of need. We expect your armies to march to our aid.
I expect, no, demand, that you aid our defence. You spoke the words of agreement, now act on them!
Your warriors have outstayed their welcome. It is time for them to leave our lands.
Seeking our protection is the only sensible course. It is good that you have seen that.
You will enjoy the safety we can provide - and you will, of course, keep up your part of the bargain.
Our wise women have looked into the flame; they see no good in trade with you.
Well met! I, the devoted servant of my people, speak to one we would name a friend.
Our lands are closed to your armies. We can no longer offer unhindered passage.
Your host is no longer welcome in Palmyrene lands. I am sure you will understand.
I ask that you stop marching in our lands. The gods are offended by foreigners.
The blessings of the gods be ours today. I ask only for ears willing to listen.
Tyrant! Dictator! Despot! Monster! Child-killer! Never shall we bow in obedience to you. That is madness!
The deal I am here to discuss favours us both.
Let us speak together. Great deeds are not achieved without careful consideration.
The priests have read the guts of a sheep, and inform me that our meeting is propitious.
Our warriors tread many paths, but they do not wish to trample your honour. May they enter your lands\?
Pharaoh has quite a taste for opulence. Do you know how to satisfy it\?
We are bonded by blood, honour and war. It is the will of the gods that you unite with us.
Tyrant! Dictator! Despot! Monster! Child-killer! Never shall we bow in obedience to you. That is madness!
This is not a sensible proposition. Perhaps you have a stolen camel you wish to sell instead\?
A foreigner will never understand that the blessing of Pharaoh, the Mother of all, cannot be bought merely for gold.
After such insolence to the Pharaoh's majesty I should take your foul skin for my shield! Keep your armies away!
Someone of your intellect and power surely recognises the benefits of cooperation with us.
Have not omens shown that the gods will welcome a treaty\? Do not offend the gods, I beg you!
I humbly propose this in the hope that you will see the merit of closer ties with our people.
So, you think of Egyptians as your mercenaries, to be expended in your futile attacks\?
We beg for a treaty between our peoples, some arrangement that will give us both prosperity and strength.
Your people are widely admired and I humbly request that you consider us suitable for a treaty.
I propose, or rather ask for, a treaty to combine our forces with your considerable strength.
The bravery of men, not words, is all that lies between us now. We shall have war, and victory too!
So, you think us dotards, who will pay because we have no memory\? You fool!
Keep your money. You will need it to pay your way in the Otherworld. And it is tainted anyway…
Set aside thoughts of war for now. Trade is what concerns me today. Traders can bring prosperity to all!
I am honoured to receive you, looking forward to your erudite arguments and witty quips!
The sword was drawn, but now it is blooded. End this feud. We offer peace today, or the sword tomorrow.
There is little worth in these terms and therefore I must reject!
As you have made the effort to meet me, I will make the effort to consider what you offer.
You have reached civilised lands now. I hope you will therefore behave with civility.
You approach as a friend. We choose our friends with care, but I respect this overture.
Diplomatic missions to
Such tributes never go amiss. What a shame not everyone sees fit to make them.
Your generosity is appreciated - and fitting of course.
Your choice is clear: serve me, alive and with your honour intact, or die.
You will obey my rule from this day forward. Dare you defy me\?
Be sensible. Accept the judgement of the gods. Your days of independence are over. Bow down!
All treaties between us are ended. I, the Divine Pharaoh, have ordered it so.
You have coin to spare. It is not as though we are asking for more than you can afford.
Keep your money. You will need it to pay your way in the Otherworld. And it is tainted anyway…
One sacrifice is needed, on the altar of our goodwill. I speak of silver, of course…
Come now, let our peoples be united! Together we can find victory unmatched!
There were times when I would have overlooked such a transgression. Not anymore. Leave. Now!
Your armies have spent too long sheltering from our sun. March them away.
The Queen of Egypt gives you greetings - I come to speak plainly of my desires.
Your men have wet their feet in our rivers for the last time. Remove them from our lands.
We can ask no more. Your proposal is wise, honourable and, I hope, pregnant with future profit!
If you will allow me a small joke, I trust that your treasurer will not mind counting the money!
Our lands have riches beyond imagining, which is why we can afford to share some of our good fortune.
I am predisposed to charity, you see\? Please accept this gift and use it wisely.
A foreigner will never understand that the blessing of Pharaoh, the Mother of all, cannot be bought merely for gold.
There is much worthiness in making and abiding by treaties, particularly with Pharaoh, the honour of Egypt.
We can agree here, if the spirits wish it, to proper treaties between our peoples.
Let all our words today be weighed against the Feather of Truth and let none be found wanting!
My ancestors were quite… inventive with dolts like you. They used fire, and skinning knives. Your request\? I spit on it!
Diplomacy has failed, then, and wisdom has fled from the wits of men. I go now to find a sword…
The Queen of Egypt, most unforgetting, may be appreciative of your monetary support.
Our wise women have looked into the flame; they see no good in trade with you.
Your mother mated with dung beetles! There is no other explanation for wanting to live off others' efforts!
I think not. Our riches outshine your own treasures a thousand fold, and you would feel ashamed.
A trading agreement would suit us both do you not think\?
When a stork flew over the marketplace this morning I knew: trade with you is the will of the gods.
Do you not think it is time for the bloodshed to end\?
The priests tell me the gods are sick of war, and I know that the people are. We would have peace.
This conflict has gone on long enough. Let us call a halt, and turn our attention to more civilised concerns.
These beasts slumber, but they could wake to hunt us both. Will you strike while they sleep\?
These insolent fools need silencing. Will your mighty armies march to meet them\?
We implore you: show your strength. Engage these foes and, by so doing, put fear in many hearts…
I have words for worthy ears. For the unworthy, I have only scant regard and much less love!
For my people, I accept. If there is fault in this choice, let the gods find it in me.
The time has come to join with us, to form a permanent bond that goes beyond friendship.
My ancestors were quite… inventive with dolts like you. They used fire, and skinning knives. Your request\? I spit on it!
These swine will threaten us soon enough, so my lord offers our strength to cull the drove…
The gods rejoice when men show such good sense! We have an accord here!
The scorpion's sting is more gentle than a refusal, but a refusal is all I can offer.
The Queen of Egypt gives you greetings - I come to speak plainly of my desires.
We ask for but a single, trifling payment from one who the gods have smiled upon.
Your uncouth armies would be a blight upton Etruscan soil. They may not enter.
The queen, the mistress of many hearts, has looked and seen that you are worthy of peace.
Indeed, rarely have I been so easily convinced to see the truth. You have my agreement.
I came as a supplicant, and the gods have granted you generosity in abundance! I agree to all!
I agree, and admire your sense and clear thinking in this matter. My people will rejoice!
We had heard of your great wisdom and with this generous offer we have seen its results!
I am humbled by your honourable words. I accept. Come, we have prepared a feast of some splendour!
May the gods bless you many times over! Your wisdom brings much joy to my people!
I am genuinely startled! I did not think you could count so well!
Your mother mated with dung beetles! There is no other explanation for wanting to live off others' efforts!
Do not expect fine words, for while we have agreement here, there is no respect between us.
We Rasna are most particular in choosing our friends. Do not refuse this offer.
There is little profit in this for my people but I will stop haggling.
The benefits of walking the same path as us should be self-evident to you.
I am, in truth, uneasy, but the good of my people requires me to put aside such feelings.
My appetite for feasting has fled. The taste of acceptance is sour in my mouth.
By the flame, you offer little, but today I'm in a giving mood. We agree.
Palmyrene merchants know well when a deal is fortuitous. So be it - we accept.
Whilst I appreciate fine words, a friendly smile or even the odd gift, what I want now is aid from your army.
Perhaps you will find profit in setting aside our friendship\? Although, for the life of me, I wonder where…
Do you want our help against these folk\? My armies, the lion of the desert, stand ready.
Silence now! I am drowning in your pointless prattle!
The portents are clear. A treaty between us would please the gods. I have no wish to offend them!
Welcome, friend, welcome! I will give you a fair answer before the sun sets!
My friend, you honour this place with your arrival!
Welcome. May the blessings of the gods bring you the profit of the day!
Greetings, most excellent friend! Be at home, and speak as you would before your own hearth-fires.
Please accept as most humble audience for your terms my poor self. Now, speak as you will.
A most magnificent welcome to you and your honourable people! What wisdom do you bring\?
Be welcome! You have my full attention. My ears await your words as willing slaves!
Please, be seated and take wine to cool the head before we heat the day with words!
Greetings, my friend, greetings! I tingle with anticipation of your noble and worthy words!
The simplest gift a queen can offer: peace in exchange for trade. I would take the gift…
The pleasures of my household are yours to enjoy. First, though, the necessary burdens of diplomacy…
We find ourselves in need of military assistance. The omens imply you might consider taking on our enemies.
A wise decision. It is always pleasing when common sense wins out.
Your choice makes little sense to me. Still, at least we have seen your true colours now.
Our negotiations have been bracing, and the outcome satisfactory.
Were you drunk when you made this decision or are you always this foolish\?
Your decision is a welcome one, and gives cause for future hope.
It appears the gods have moved you to refuse us. Perhaps it is for the best, then.
The queen of Egypt, lord of Upper and Lower Egypt, expects that you will accept her proffered friendship. Immediately.
Join with your brothers and be the stronger! When all follow one banner, the sky will shake at our approach!
I am sure that you accept this treasure, drawn from the coffers of Pharaoh, the incomparably wealthy.
No temple can stand upon just two pillars. We cannot agree.
Our own riches are not so grand that they could never be improved by tribute from your people.
We require a regular tribute of gold from you. I trust you see the necessity here…
For those wise enough to see, there is profit in being generous, and more profit in remaining so.
Your intent here is plain, but to accept your money would put us in your debt.
I can sense that the gods smile on our agreement. This is an honourable matter!
This is not a sweet wine, but I drink it for the good of my people.
A freely given gift is like a gentle spring shower: unexpected and refreshing.
In your filthy hands these lands would wither like ill-cut vines. Do not take us for fools!
May your soul be as dust! These people deserve better than to be playthings for your wicked perversities.
Our lands\? Is there anything else you want\? Perhaps you'd like me for your slave\?
Had the gods wanted us to help you defend your cause they would have sent some sign. They have not.
I am sent to speak to you, and hear words. I must have offended many gods to be given this reward!
This is not a sensible proposition. Perhaps you have a stolen camel you wish to sell instead\?
Truly, your village must be missing its idiot! Pharaoh, the sun of Egypt's skies, is not for sale!
Egypt's treasury doors will remain resolutely shut. Do not look for gold here.
There is much worthiness in making and abiding by treaties, particularly with Pharaoh, the honour of Egypt.
I am told our generals must march across your lands. We have no quarrel with you, of course…
You honour me by your attention, worthy listener! I wish to speak of many matters…
Your willingness to listen brings joy and hope to my heart. This is my proposal...
The blessings of the heavens to you and yours! Kindly give attention to my words, that all may profit!
I extend my royal greeting. Do you desire to hear a worthy proposal\?
May the gods smile on our meeting, that we may both profit by it!
Yes, it's very nice gold, but the portents indicate that we should never take it from scum.
Greetings, most honourable one! Palmyra requires but a smidgen of your time, and your patience shall be repaid tenfold.
I search not for debate and discord, but for your most worthy attention.
May the gods of east and west bless this portentous meeting! Hear my words and decide!
I bring terms that I trust will be of keen interest to the ear of one so honourable and wise.
Consider the advantages of joining this conflict: honour for your armies, and the gratitude of Etruria.
Can you not find it in your noble hearts to allow passage to divine Pharaoh's armies\?
Carrion birds and jackals will grow fat on your carcasses, and lose the taste for your rancid flesh!
Let us trade. You surely will not turn aside from a road paved with gold\?
Pleasant greetings to you, worthy representative of a great people! I hope for your fleeting attention…
The scorpion's sting is more gentle than a refusal, but a refusal is all I can offer.
We do not pay wolves to keep them from our flocks. When we can be bothered, we hunt them.
You are under the mistaken impression that we must buy our friendships, we who settled these lands in the time of the gods.
You have fine goods that many here would enjoy. Can I not persuade you to trade with us\?
I swear in Baalshamin's name that my torturers will prepare something special for you!
We shall put aside words and draw the bow. The arrow will strike where it will, and widows will weep.
War it is then! I look forward to it! I relish it! I tingle at the thought of your cities aflame!
So be it! I shall be the midwife who delivers your demise!
Look to your gods, and pray, for only in them will you now find mercy.
The generals of Palmyra will burn your cities, towns, villages, every little straw hut, until the sky is dark with smoke!
Honourable enemies we will be in war! I trust, my once-friend, your people will fall into darkness and despair!
Now that words have failed, become an undertaker. That way, you may profit from this war!
Return to your people and prepare them for death. That is now your only duty.
I plead for peace, not from cowardice but from concern. If we fight on, only our rivals profit…
We seek trade and prosperity for all. I am sure that you can see that, in your noble wisdom…
Our enemies watch with glee while we bleed in the uncaring dust. Shall we spite our foes, and have peace\?
Your merchants are renowned as skilled and honourable traders. They would be made welcome in our markets!
We have all asked much of our warriors. Now, I beg, let us give them rest.
I respectfully ask that you consider opening your markets to our traders, for that way profit flows to all.
There is hardly a more worthy foe than you under the sun. I wish to sue for peace.
Do you have enough glory to be merciful\? Can I ask for peace, and hope for its coming\?
Let there be peace, I beg. Surely now there has been enough bloodshed and misery\?
Your troops are enjoying our hospitality. Perhaps it is time, however, to seek it somewhere else\?
We weary of being good hosts to your armies. Have them march away while we still have some wine!
Last night, in a dream, I saw your troops marching from our lands. Will you make my dream come true\?
Are you cowards, or fools\? These people must be dealt with now!
Treaty between us would see our people both stronger and richer. Is there need of further embellishment\?
You insolence is well attested and demonstrated. Be careful, or I will demonstrate some inventive cruelty!
You mistake politeness for concern as to your wellbeing. If all your people died, I would merely thank the gods.
Your people are lower than camel dung, drying in the desert sun, yet you propose a treaty\? Bah!
Palmyrene warriors shall never march alongside the rabble you call an army!
Your sickening ideas of what is right and proper are beyond my understanding.
As Yarhibol is my witness, do you really think I would tarnish my good name by allying with the likes of you\?
The bond between our peoples is broken. Do not look for us when you are in need.
With the riches at your command, we are hoping you can spare a small regular contribution to our coffers.
My proud people treasure the blood-bond between us. Do you not see it too\? Will you join us\?
The queen, mighty steward of her people, is pleased that you've seen sense.
The marketplace will grow quiet, and many will weep at this ending, for wealth is dear to all.
Our traders will look for new markets. They are adventurous and will enjoy the challenge!
It is trade that nourishes your lands as well as mine, yet you would see them both famished\?
Whilst your proposition shows due appreciation of our warriors' talents, we see no gain for ourselves in this.
I am genuinely startled! I did not think you could count so well!
Our gates must remain closed and barred, even to your glorious armies.
Palmyrene hospitality extends to all worthy soldiers… with the exception of yours!
I am sorry, my friend, but our gods would be much offended by the presence of your soldiers.
Come, noble visitor, sit and ease your worries by speaking with the Pharaoh, divine mistress of Egypt.
Even the strongest must put down the sword. Can you not see that the time for peace is here\?
Truly, your village must be missing its idiot! Pharaoh, the sun of Egypt's skies, is not for sale!
Grant me but a trifling sum and your name will be a blessing in Palmyra.
A regular reminder of friendship, perhaps in gold, would keep you forever in my thoughts.
Dear friend, giving money is an investment in a peaceful future. I am sure you know how to proceed…
I may be lenient but there is a limit to compassion. Today, Palmyra rides to war!
You want our gold\? And just a little, you say\? Well I want many things, not least to be left in peace.
I pity the mothers, wives and sisters of your soldiers, for they are about to lose the men they cherish.
Any glory you buy with blood will soon tarnish, for you are a people without honour and worth.
The storm has raged long, but now, with your agreement, the softer rains of peace could be felt.
War it shall be if that is your desire. I hope that you have already paid the mourners!
War, my friend... no! My enemy! War is an expensive business. Be sure you can pay the blood reckoning!
War, my friend, is like wine. Taken in excess it leads to madness and death! I wish you both!
And thus you have invoked the queen's wrath. For you there will be no mercy!
When your lands are awash with your blood you may come to regret foolish notions of glory.
We will blacken the sky with arrows and each will strike a victim through the heart!
May the malevolent gods curse you and blight you! May your swords shatter! May your bows break!
Were I to lay awake all night, staring at the Moon, my answer would still be a resounding No.""
Ah! You think me a fool blinded by the love of gold, and with sun-addled brains. The answer is No!""
Athena has blessed you with the wisdom to speak well. She has blessed me with the wisdom to say No.""
The gods have not yet made us mad, so the answer will be a polite No.""
